item.title: Activity 1
item.description:
The following activity is aimed to give you some practice with exploring data on your own using statistical software. You are welcome to use any statistical software you wish and you are also free to work in groups of up to 3 for this assignment. If you work in groups, please submit one completed activity per group on ICON. Please make sure to add everyone’s name to the submission, this can be a comment on ICON or on the document itself.

Instructions

What to turn in

Please turn in a document that contains the following:

  1. answers to the questions below
  2. include any relevant statistics/figures that support your answer.

Finally, upload the final document to ICON.

Due Date

Due around September 19th, 2021. No penalty for late submissions as long as it is submitted by December 11th.

Data

The data for this activity comes from the Tidy Tuesday project. The data contain 73 rows and 22 columns about ferris wheels from around the world. A data description for each column in the data is shown below (see the Tidy Tuesday page for more information)

The data can be obtained in csv format. A short description for each attribute is as follows. These data are also found within the “data” folder inside the IDAS.

Attribute Name Type Description
name character Name
height double Height in feet
diameter double Diameter in feet
opened double ISO Date opened
closed double ISO date closed
country character Country
location character Location/city/region
number_of_cabins integer Number of cabins
passengers_per_cabin integer Passengers per cabin
seating_capacity integer Seating capacity
hourly_capacity integer Hourly capacity
ride_duration_minutes double Ride duration minutes
climate_controlled character climate_controlled
construction_cost character construction_cost
status character status
design_manufacturer character design_manufacturer
type character type
vip_area character vip_area
ticket_cost_to_ride character ticket_cost_to_ride
official_website character official_website
turns double turns

Questions

  1. Pick a single integer or double attribute from the table above and explore the distribution of that attribute. In a few sentences, summarize key elements of the distribution, for instance discussing elements related to shape, center, variation, and/or extreme values.

  2. Pick a few attributes (i.e., pick your top 3 favorite) that are of the double or integer type and explore the bivariate association between those attributes. That is, estimate what is the bivariate association between the attributes you chose. In a few sentences, summarize key elements of the associations, paying attention to the strength and direction of association.

  3. Explore the bivariate associations you picked in #2 visually. Does the relationship appear to be linear for the associations that you picked? Why or why not?

  4. Pick a single integer or double attribute from the table above. Compute descriptive statistics for this attribute using one of the following attributes as a grouping attribute:

  • climate_controlled

  • type_two

    More specifically, compute descriptive statistics for the integer or double outcome for each unique value of either climate_controlled or type_two.

  1. Summarize, in a few sentences, any notable differences or similarities in the descriptive statistics computed in #4 across the groups?

item.title: Activity 2
item.description:
The following activity is aimed to give you some practice with exploring data and running a linear regression on your own using statistical software. You are welcome to use any statistical software you wish and you are also free to work in groups of up to 3 for this assignment. If you work in groups, please submit one completed activity per group on ICON. Please make sure to add everyone’s name to the submission, this can be a comment on ICON or on the document itself.

Instructions

What to turn in

Please turn in a document that contains the following:

  1. answers to the questions below
  2. include any relevant statistics/figures that support your answer.

Finally, upload the final document to ICON.

Due Date

Due around October 3rd, 2022. No penalty for late submissions as long as it is submitted by December 11th.

Data

The data for this activity is rideshare data from about three weeks in 2018 for Boston, MA. The data originally come from Kaggle. I have done some processing to randomly select 2,500 records from the larger data for our use and have trimmed down the data attributes.

The data can be obtained in csv format. A short description for each attribute is as follows.

Attribute Name Description
id Unique identifier for each row
hour The hour of the ride
day The day of the ride
month The month of the ride, either 11 = November or 12 = December
price The total price of the ride, in $
temperature The outside temperature at the time of the ride, in Fahrenheit
distance Total distance of the ride, in miles
surge_multiplier The surge multiplier for the cost of rides
humidity The humidity at the time of the ride

Guiding Question

Does the distance of the ride explain variation in the price of the ride?

Questions

  1. Explore the distribution of the price of the rides descriptively. In a few sentences, summarize key elements of the distribution, for instance discussing elements related to shape, center, variation, and/or extreme values.

  2. Explore the bivariate distribution of the price of ride and distance of rides. In a few sentences, summarize key elements of the relationship between price and distance. You may wish to include the following elements of the association, strength, direction, and/or form.

  3. Does the association between price and distance of rides appear to be linear? Why or why not?

  4. Fit a linear regression to answer the research question highlighted above. Interpret the intercept and slope of the linear regression. That is, what do these terms mean?

  5. What are the r-squared and sigma estimates from the linear regression? Interpret these two values in the context of the problem. That is, what do these two terms mean in the context of the data and this problem?

  6. Finally, in a couple sentences, provide a summary of the overall model. Does the model appear to be useful to predict the price of a ride with only the distance of the ride? Use statistics from the analysis steps above to support your answer.

item.title: Activity 3
item.description:
The following activity is aimed to give you some practice with exploring data and running a linear regression on your own using statistical software. You are welcome to use any statistical software you wish and you are also free to work in groups of up to 3 for this assignment. If you work in groups, please submit one completed activity per group on ICON. Please make sure to add everyone’s name to the submission, this can be a comment on ICON or on the document itself.

Instructions

What to turn in

Please turn in a document that contains the following:

  1. answers to the questions below
  2. include any relevant statistics/figures that support your answer.

Finally,upload the final document to ICON.

Due Date

Due around October 17th, 2021. No penalty for late submissions as long as it is submitted by December 11th.

Data

The data for this activity is rideshare data from about three weeks in 2018 for Boston, MA. The data originally come from Kaggle. I have done some processing to randomly select 2,500 records from the larger data for our use and have trimmed down the data attributes.

Note: Use the data linked here or posted to the IDAS. The data can be obtained in csv format. A short description for each attribute is as follows.

Attribute Name Description
id Unique identifier for each row
hour The hour of the ride
day The day of the ride
month The month of the ride, either 11 = November or 12 = December
price The total price of the ride, in $
temperature The outside temperature at the time of the ride, in Fahrenheit
distance Total distance of the ride, in miles
surge_multiplier The surge multiplier for the cost of rides
humidity The humidity at the time of the ride

Guiding Question

Does the distance of the ride explain variation in the price of the ride?

Questions

  1. This assignment uses the same data from the second activity. Take a few minutes to reacquaint yourself with this analysis, including the linear regression estimates obtained.

  2. Was the intercept from the linear regression fitted in activity 2 using the raw data as it was collected interpretable in the context of the data? Rephrasing slightly, could the intercept term be made more interpretable? If so, how?

  3. Fit a modified linear regression that performs a centering. That is, center the distance in some fashion. Options could include, minimum, mean, median, maximum, etc centering. What changed for the estimates obtained from the model?

    • Which model, the centered or the uncentered, do you feel has a stronger justification for its usage? Be as specific as possible in your rationale.

  4. Use whichever model you feel is the best from #3, then extract from software or compute the standard errors for the estimated regression coefficients. Interpret these standard errors in the context of the problem.

  5. Compute confidence intervals for the two regression coefficients. Justify your choice for level of confidence and interpret the confidence interval.

  6. Finally, perform hypothesis testing for the two regression coefficients. In this, set up the null/alternative hypotheses and then interpret the statistical results to provide a statistical conclusion. More specifically, what does the hypothesis test suggest about the null and alternative hypotheses?

    • The first part talked about the statistical conclusions, now compare/contrast this with practical conclusions. More specifically, would these results be useful in practice? Be as specific as possible in your response.

item.title: Activity 4
item.description:
The following activity is aimed to give you some practice with exploring data and running a linear regression on your own using statistical software. You are welcome to use any statistical software you wish and you are also free to work in groups of up to 3 for this assignment. If you work in groups, please submit one completed activity per group on ICON. Please make sure to add everyone’s name to the submission, this can be a comment on ICON or on the document itself.

Instructions

What to turn in

Please turn in a document that contains the following:

  1. answers to the questions below
  2. include any relevant statistics/figures that support your answer.

Finally,upload the final document to ICON.

Due Date

Due around October 31st, 2022. No penalty for late submissions as long as it is submitted by December 11th.

Data

The data for this activity is rideshare data from about three weeks in 2018 for Boston, MA. The data originally come from Kaggle. I have done some processing to randomly select 2,500 records from the larger data for our use and have trimmed down the data attributes.

Note: Use the data linked here or posted to the IDAS. The data can be obtained in csv format. A short description for each attribute is as follows.

Attribute Name Description
id Unique identifier for each row
hour The hour of the ride
day The day of the ride
month The month of the ride, either 11 = November or 12 = December
price The total price of the ride, in $
temperature The outside temperature at the time of the ride, in Fahrenheit
distance Total distance of the ride, in miles
surge_multiplier The surge multiplier for the cost of rides
humidity The humidity at the time of the ride

Guiding Question

Does the distance of the ride explain variation in the price of the ride?

Questions

  1. This assignment uses the same data from the first and second activities. Take a few minutes to reacquaint yourself with these analyses, including the linear regression estimates obtained.

  2. Extract the residuals from one of the linear regressions using the centered or uncentered regressions (it doesn’t matter which one). Perform a descriptive analysis on these residuals. This could include graphically visualizing the distribution and/or computing summary statistics on the residuals.

  3. Evaluate the residuals for the assumption of normality of the residuals. How may the results be impacted by any deviation of normality?

  4. Evaluate the residuals for the assumption of homogeneity of variance. How may the results be impacted by any deviation of homogeneity of variance?

  5. Are there any noticeable trends in the residuals? What implications could this have for the analysis? If a trend in the residuals exists, what may be a cause for this trend?

  6. Explore the model to identify if there are any points that have high leverage or could be identified as extreme values. It may be worth exploring studentized residuals, cook’s distance, and/or leverage values.

item.title: Activity 5
item.description:
The following activity is aimed to give you some practice with exploring data and running a linear regression on your own using statistical software. You are welcome to use any statistical software you wish and you are also free to work in groups of up to 3 for this assignment. If you work in groups, please submit one completed activity per group on ICON. Please make sure to add everyone’s name to the submission, this can be a comment on ICON or on the document itself.

Instructions

What to turn in

Please turn in a document that contains the following:

  1. answers to the questions below
  2. include any relevant statistics/figures that support your answer.

Finally,upload the final document to ICON.

Due Date

Due around November 14th, 2022. No penalty for late submissions as long as it is submitted by December 11th.

Data

The data for this activity is San Francisco rental data. The data originally come from Tidy Tuesday. I have done some processing to drop some missing data and remove some attributes from the larger data for our use.

Note: Use the data linked here or posted to the IDAS. The data can be obtained in csv format. A short description for each attribute is as follows.

Attribute Name Description
post_id Unique ID
date date
year year
nhood neighborhood
city city
county county
price price in USD
beds n of beds
sqft square feet of rental
room_in_apt room in apartment

Guiding Questions

  1. Does the square footage (sqft) of the rental help explain variation in the price of the rental?
  2. After controlling for the square footage of the rental, does the number of bedrooms help explain any additional variation in the price of the rental?

Questions

  1. Explore descriptively any relationship between square footage and price of the rental. Summarize the relationship in a couple sentences.

  2. Fit a model to explore research question 1, summarize in a few sentences the primary regression estimates.

  3. There are two ways to estimate this model, treat number of bedrooms as continuous or as a factor. Fit this model in both ways: a. Treat bedrooms as continuous (simply add bedrooms into the model). b. Treat bedrooms as a categorical/ordinal attribute. In R, you can do this with the following code: factor(beds) in the model equation.

  4. Interpret the regression estimates for the effect of number of bedrooms from each model in #3.

  5. What is a key difference in the assumed form of the relationship between both models in #3?

  6. Perform model comparisons for the 3 models fitted in this activity. That is, compare the following models:

    • square footage only
    • square footage with continuous bedrooms
    • square footage with categorical/ordinal bedrooms. Identify for each model comparison if the model is nested or not nested and interpret the appropriate model comparison measure.
